title: Can I declare bankruptcy to stop a default judgment if the clerk has just entered my default at the bank's request?
question: I was served papers by a creditor 2 1/2 months ago. I misunderstood the court calendar and thought I had 110 days to respond (not 30 days).
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Automatic stays in bankruptcy,Debt,Lien,Bankruptcy and debt,Fraud,Lawsuits and disputes,Default judgment
answers:
You can certainly file bankruptcy to discharge a default judgment so long as it is a judgment not for fraud or other tortious activity. However, I would recommend seeking competent bankruptcy counsel to determine if a bankruptcy makes sense in your situation. For example, do you have other unsecured debts? Are you behind on your house payments? How much are they seeking in the judgment? What are the causes of actions in the complaint?

My colleague is correct. Filing for bankruptcy will put Automatic Stay in place so that the negative effects of the judgment will cease.

I also recommend that you seek the advice of a bankruptcy attorney in your area (whether through me or another attorney in your area). Bankruptcy sometimes isn't the right fit for everyone. Your income and asset situation will help determine what chapter bankruptcy is best for you.

The one other point that I would like to make is that you should take quick action in addressing the judgment issue. The creditor is able to do the following to you when they have a judgment: 1) garnish your wages up to 25% of your net income, 2) levy your bank accounts, 3) put a lien against your property. Since there is a judgment against you, time is a factor.

While bankruptcy will stop any further proceeding in that lawsuit, including the entry of judgment, it may not be the correct path. There may be other wats to stop the judgment from being entered, such as filing a motion to set aside the default. Since you did not give any details as to the nature of the lawsuit or as to your financial situation, it is impossible to say at this point whether bankruptcy is the right choice for you. I would meet with an attorney who can discuss your specific situation and let you know how to best proceed.
